The two scenes involving characters reading lists don't help either.

A female killer is a constant trope in giallos, i.e. Italian slashers from the 60's and 70's. Look into the films by Dario Argento and Mario Bava and you'll find multiple examples of female killers. Since giallos are "whodunits" I don't want to give the specific titles away.

WRITING.TEXT: Yes, I have considered it - will implement given that I have the free time.

Selecting "Up" yields only films older than the queried film. Consider that the inferred inspirations, the "ancestors" higher up in the lineage tree (Cinetrii = Cinema, tree). Conversely, "Down" yields films which the queried one has inspired.
[Better?](http://cinetrii.com?i=tt0910970) Unusual letters in the data sets can mess things up sometimes.

They hire directors who mostly have worked with TV, which means the producers have more creative control. Thus the movies can conform to the same safe, bland look. Plus, most of the budget goes to the main stars, which leaves little in terms of production.

The analysis of Silence of the Lambs is completely spurious and sophomoric. However, I do think that the proliferation of video essays like these ultimately is a good thing because it bolsters interest in the medium. Some of my friends who only enjoy mainstream blockbuster fare have still been able to appreciate something like Tony Zhou's take on Michael Bay.
Bringing up YMS as some paragon of film criticism makes no sense, his top ten lists notwithstanding. He spends most of his time laughing at roadkill and adapting CinemaSins to essay form.
[After all these years..](http://i.imgur.com/E8uyfPu.jpg)

My [movie search engine](http://cinetrii.com?i=tt0469494) tries to find thematic connections, and besides Citizen Kane which people have already pointed out, theres [Giant](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0049261/). I haven't seen it, but it seems similar in scope and ambition.

Hey there, a couple of weeks ago I posted about my project in popular education, [Cinetrii](http://www.cinetrii.com). It's a tool which tries to find artistic lineage between films by parsing written reviews.
I'm slowly rolling out a change to the algorithm so that it favors popular films less. For example, the results for Tarantino's work is now more [relevant](http://cinetrii.com?i=tt3460252) than it used to be. Previously, a given Tarantino film query resulted mostly in other Tarantino films.

Spread the word, and you can also donate to cover the server costs (link at the bottom of the page).
I am thinking of implementing some sort per-title rating system so users can vote if they think the tree is interesting or not. That way I can easier survey the results and modify the algorithm.

For the last couple of months I've worked on a film discussion-related experiment called [Cinetrii](http://cinetrii.com?i=tt4062536). I try to find connections between films, such as reoccuring motifs and themes, algorithmically by parsing online reviews. The results aren't always relevant but often interesting nontheless. I think you guys would like it.

My title is a bit misleading. Pasting an explanation from elsewhere:
The goal was to infer the artistic influences at work for a given movie. Of course, there are multiple biases at play here. Ive already covered the unequal distribution of available reviews in my original blog post. Furthermore, art is only as interesting as the conversation around it, and not all movies warrant fine-grained reflection. Even for those movies that do, the connections are mostly speculative. Critics are not clairvoyant, they cant know what directors were inspired by. Cinetrii approximates the perception of movie critics more than anything else.

Thank you. I'm continually tuning the heuristics, but in many cases the lack of available data produce some very noisy results. The intent is really to trace re-use of motifs, plots etc for educational purposes. [Dev blog](http://cinetrii.com/blog/)

WRITING.TITLE: Cinetrii - Find similar movies based on inferences by film critics
